qas.question: In what era was a geocentric view of the universe adopted?
Who was able to describe the process of evaporation?
What object was assumed to block sunlight during a lunar eclipse?
What did astronomers believe the shape of the Sun to be during this era?
What did astronomers during this area believe to be the center of the universe?

context: <a0_0>Han<a0_0/>-era astronomers adopted a geocentric model of the universe, theorizing that it was shaped like a sphere surrounding <a4_0>the earth<a4_0/> in the center. They assumed that the Sun, Moon, and planets were <a3_0>spherical<a3_0/> and not disc-shaped. They also thought that the illumination of the Moon and planets was caused by sunlight, that lunar eclipses occurred when <a2_0>the Earth<a2_0/> obstructed sunlight falling onto the Moon, and that a solar eclipse occurred when the Moon obstructed sunlight from reaching the Earth. Although others disagreed with his model, <a1_0>Wang Chong<a1_0/> accurately described the water cycle of the evaporation of water into clouds.
